content:
Posted: December 28, 2015
												(Adaptation of my Grimrock 2 review.)Getting lost in this huge dungeon is so great. Even in the age of Witcher 3, this game shows that grid-based movement can still be fun. I have a hard time explaining why but here are some possible factors:- Enemies feel more menacing because you can't circle-strafe them, play with aggro range or exploit pathfinding bugs against them like in most free movement rpgs/fpss. So the dungeon feels more claustrophobic and menacing... I definitely don't feel that in Skyrim dungeons.- Mapping out the dungeon square by square and paying close attention to your environment for secret buttons and switches feels great, and it's not the typical modern RPG experience. A free movement game can hardly hide a button somewhere on a wall and expect you to find it, here with the constrained views it works.- The grid system allows for some very smart puzzles, I have to admit I sometimes give up and consult a walkthrough, but I enjoy their presence nonetheless!And you get to control (read: juggle) 4 characters, so four times the RPG goodness!All in all, you'll like it if you liked old-school RPGs like Dungeon Master, Eye of the Beholder and Lands of Lore: Throne of Chaos. But if you haven't played those games you should try it anyways! You might very well find that grid-based movement is a bit like pixel art: originally born of technical limitations, it can still bring a unique and interesting twist to a game.Once you're done with this one check out Grimrock 2! It's bigger, more varied visually and less linear. The modding scene is also flourishing for both games, though I suspect mods for the second game must be better, modders have more material and a more advanced engine to work with.

Posted: December 1, 2013
												Legend of Grimrock is an accessible dungeon crawler with fun and engrossing puzzles; the kind of puzzles that aren't complicated but require a decent understanding of the point-and-click mechanics. Unfortunately most of the underwhelming puzzles require hugging the wall and hunting down hidden wall switches.The RPG mechanics are pretty barebones. The combat consist of mindless clicking and side-stepping. You'll most likely never reach the end level class skills in your first playthough without excessive grinding. The only redeemable aspect of combat is the spellcasting system. In Grimrock, using magic spells require you enter the correct combinations of runes, as if you are dialing them on a keypad. Learning new rune combinations through the scrolls found in the dungeon is always an enjoyable treat. I only beat the main campaign but it took me roughly 10 hours not counted on Steam as my internet connection was down for a period of time. The user submitted workshop dungeons could hypothetically add even more unique playtime with this but I haven't had a clue if they are as good as the main game. Grimrock is well worth the full price by itself, though.One final note is that if you are of faint of heart you might not enjoy this game as it throws you a ton of creepy creatures that run around in the darkness of the dungeon.

Posted: April 27, 2012
												So, you want an old school RPG adventure ? This is it ! Legend Of Grimrock starts you off with 4 prisoners, in a mountain, consisting of 13 levels. These levels are filled with puzzles, evil creatures, traps and more and, obviously, it gets increasingly difficult along the way.However, the difficulty is a bit random at times. Near the end it took me literally minutes to take down one enemy, even though I had some proper spells and weapons. There are moments where you will be overwhelmed by quite a few enemies. Remember to save often, and try not to lose any of your party members before you reached the end of a level. I had to finish a level with just one rogue and it took me 3-4x longer than it should've.The game can be finished in about 10-12 hours (in-game time) but in reality it should take you about twice as long. You will die several times, and some puzzles require thinking, experimenting or just plain luck. But despite the difficulty, I did have a great time with it ![Rating: 82/100]

content:
Posted: February 13, 2014
												A modern take on the old-school tile-based dungeon crawler, was something of a surprise hit. Blending a close to perfect mix of horror, suspense, mystery, puzzles, and combat, Legend of Grimrock enticed my inner adventurer. The game itself is quite enjoyable, the grim-dark atmosphere lends itself perfectly to the setting, and the tile-based movement adds an interesting mechanic to it all. The is a game where you will make mistakes, there’s no avoiding that, you will fumble and fall and lose party members and grumble as you backtrack to a crystal. You’ll jump and curse when spiders sneak up on you, groan and rage as traps trigger and surround you with enemies, and kick yourself for not saving more often. You’ll experiment in the skill tree and find out that you’ve invested in something useless, or that you’ve given points wrong, or expended one-use items on the wrong character. Sometimes you’ll wish you’d taken the other loot, or wondered what was in the other locked room, so you’ll reload and find out, then compare before reloading again and deciding. You’ll rage as monsters surround you, you’ll rage as you find a character suddenly out of ammo, mana, poisoned, or just plain dead. You’ll rage as you run from Ogres, you’ll rage as Fire Elementals hit your back-row characters, you’ll rage as you’re confronted with new horrors the dungeon has to offer. But most of all, you will rage at the puzzles.The game does not hold your hand, which is both beautiful and mildly infuriating at times. There’s a lot of trial an error when it comes to solving puzzles, and you will die a lot trying. But that’s what this game is, a lot of trial and error. It can be harsh, but it’s never unfair, so long as you use your brain and save every 5 minutes. The only genuine complaint I have with the game is the inventory/loot system; space was simple to manage so long as you saved your sacks and boxes, but the weight mechanic was a little challenging at times, when I discover that the Kayran Nipple I just looted and put in a character’s inventory has weighed them down and has made the party slow as hell. What really got me was that there was no loot selling or anything like that, things just became obsolete and you had no reason to keep them, other than maybe convenient replacements for rocks.All in all I love this game to death, and had that rare compulsion to play it every second I had free time, though the game is best enjoyed, in my opinion, in longer sessions. That way you remember all the little details you were going over and you don’t miss out on something. That being said, I went over the entire dungeon with a fine-toothed come and still managed to miss some secrets, as the statistics will tell you. Half-way through my first playthrough I realized my lizardman rogue was relatively useless when I could have just gone double fighter mage combo, since I had teched him into ranged and throwing. And that was a mistake. You MUST specialize your character if you want to survive, if you choose to go down swords, you stick with swords, if you want axes, don’t switch out for maces because you found one and it was better, and try to keep to one or two disciplines of magic.For anyone who likes grim-dark fantasy, dungeon crawling, RPG’s, mystery, puzzles, and/or tile-based combat, Legend of Grimrock is definitely a must. Your inner loot-♥♥♥♥♥ will be pleased, your inner puzzler will be perplexed, and your inner adventurer will be grinning all the while. Enter Mount Grimrock, and make your way to the horrors within, best of luck.

												"Why aren't you playing Skyrim instead" came to mind when I played this for the first time. Nostalgia is why. This is oldskool gaming so those new to this may find it a little simplistic. I played the classic Dungeon Master for ages on my Atari ST and thought it was the best thing. Ever. LoG has simple controls (makes a nice change these days) and you move around in a shuffling chess like fashion. My imagination was working a little more than it usually is picturing my hairy Warrior clad in his leather pants and brandishing a brutal looking cudgel. You can customise the portraits (Homer Simpson as Warrior anyone?) so you could have the Dixie Chicks going around whacking the heck out of everything. Remember to use the quick save often because death is permanent.  It would be a better World if there was a tablet version of this.

content:
Posted: April 1, 2015
												Ok, I just marathoned through Grimrock 1 and 2 and thought I would conclude that with a concise review.In short : the games are unbelievably good. Admittedly, this was the first time I've ever played a first person dungeon crawler with classic grid-based movement, but there is very little I can actually criticize.The puzzles are extremely well designed. Even though it usually took me few minutes to go from "This♥♥♥♥♥♥makes no sense at all, what the hell!" to "ohhhh, I get it!", it felt all the more rewarding when I finally managed to solve a particularly difficult puzzle all on my own.The first game manages to create a great gloomy atmosphere, when you delve into pitch black dungeons, devoid of any other human being, and when you can hear the various critters crawl somewhere on the other side of a wall. I would even say, it's not too far off from what a horror game feels like.The successor has a much more open and interconnected world, with differently themed areas, both above and below the surface, similar to how the first Dark Souls approached level design (including the bit where you aimlessly wander around in already cleared areas, looking for the entrance to the next dungeon). It may not be quite as eerie as the first Grimrock game, but the first mimic you encounter in the game will make sure to give you a heart attack regardless.The only thing left to say is : Don't play them on hard mode on your first play through, like I did, or else you're in for a lot of frustration. The games do have a few really cheap moments, the second one even more so than the first one. Because if there's one thing the developers really like, it's trying to make you fall down into a monster infested trap pit, which spells inevitable death. Few things are more infuriating than finding and activating a hidden switch on a wall, only to be mauled by a dozen monsters crawling in from all directions a few seconds later. Now, combine that with an incredibly clunky combat system (Grid-based attacks and movement. In real time. Why...?) which in itself poses enough of a challenge, when enemies can kill your front line in two hits, and you'll find yourself dangerously close to throwing something valuable out of the window. I'm pretty sure I'm not the only one who would have loved to have turn based battles, like in Wizardry 8 for example, in these games.

												A stirling effort from Almost Human Games here in their (in my view) near, if not flawless re-visitation of a classic genre; it pays well - earned homage to the pioneers of the genre - Eye of the Beholder, etc - as without their contributions to the multifarious world of gaming, we would never have seen such a remarkable title, namely the Legend of Grimrock, nominally reflecting its plot seamlessly.In time, with further refinements, if even necessary, heeding the game industry's inexorable technological progression & evolution (possibly in the form of a sequel, alluded to by the game's dev's on the LoG website), I could easily expect their respectively held positions in gaming legend to invert, seeing LoG as one of the superlative titles of our generation, as its, in terms of genre, preceding titles were to theirs.

content:
Posted: April 12, 2012
												Summary:Grimrock is a first person (first party in this case) dungeon crawl.  If you've ever heard/played a game called Stonekeep (late 1990s), you'll enjoy this game too.  Well designed, immersive, and an absolutely beautiful sound track.  Some skill is required to be a magic caster / use magic in your party, but if you get good at it, you really feel you've earned the title "mage."Overall Score:  Worth Getting (Niche game)  -- ( 79/100)Gameplay:  (56/60 points)Mechanics (35/35 points) – rules/physics/noticeable glitchesI have never encountered any bugs while playing Grimrock.  The rules of the world fit very well with the challenges you face and you never feel like the game is cheating.Controls (8/10 points) – ease of operation / button dynamicsControls are very basic, left, right, back, forward, casting is difficult, but in a good way where you feel really good when you successfully cast a spell.  My only beef with the controls was inventory managment.  Trying to maintain 4 peoples inventory was very cumbersome at times.Difficulty ( 5/5 points) – how hard is it to progress & does this difficulty work for or against the playerThe game trains you as you go.  The first few levels are about learning how things work.  It's a good build up and by later in the game, it's about exploration, adapting and facing challenges that force you to use everything you've learned up to that point.Immersion ( 4/5 points) –  very subjective:  Being drawn into the gameThe environments are realistic enough and the sounds and music will make you forget about everything around you.  The desire to save as often as possible and searching for secrets areas and having to look up a few solutions was the only thing that broke immersion for me.Fun ( 3/5 points)– very subjective: other enjoyment factorsVERY fun, but not so fun that I actually finished the game.  It was still excellent though, I've gotten further into this game than most.Content:  (20/35 points)Story (13/15 points) – Does it exist, coherent, presentation of, and does it enhance game play?The opening was excellent, there's little scraps of papers and books that tell you more of the story thorugh the ponderings of a former "inmate."  Also every level of the game tells a different story and as you move further in, the very walls and status hint at darker things that have gone into the formation of Grimrock.  I can't say that the story is deep, but it is enjoyable. Characters (5/10 points) – Interesting, well developed, work with gameplay and storyThe characters are fairly standard fare for your Dungeons and Dragons -esque setting, but the manual had some great backstory on each.  It doesn't play into the game, but was good flavor text.“S.S.D.D.” value (2/10 points) – abilities, roles, tools, NPCs, and general world setting uniquenessVery typical for a dungeon crawl. Gamer Parent Factors:  (3/5 GOLDEN points)- (WIN) Ability to save / pause and come back later to pick it up right away again- (WIN) Ability to progress during short gameplay sessions (30 mins – 1.5 hours)- (WIN) Replay value and game length not related to required repetitive grinding to increase stats-  (NO)  Ability to play game with spouse or offspring-  (NO)  Availability on multiple platformsGamerDad Game Reviews -- Purpose and CriteriaThe purpose of GamerDad Game reviews is to evaluate ‘aged’ games that have been on the market long enough to experience a substantial price drop from their original industry standard price. Reviewing games towards the end of their life cycle will offer an updated consumer valuation of the game based on if known issues have been fixed since release, value of optional DLC (Downloadable Content made available after initial game release) to gameplay, and if the entertainment return on investment is worth the new price point.

												Legitimately the best game I've ever played. Great puzzles, great combat mechanics, great story and (most of all) IMMERSION. It's saddening so many games lack this. So they must survive while there are monsters everywhere, disgusting food, a strange dream that happens sometimes when you rest, creepy sounds and amazing atmosphere. The graphics add so much to the atmosphere too because they look very amazing and somehow this game runs very well on my terrible PC. I wish more games did that.There are 3 main parts to this game and I will review each aspect one by one:CombatPuzzle SolvingExplorationCombat-The combat in this game is an old school style one, you're party is in 4 people all linked together and you walk on square tiles. You have to gather up weapons from monsters, hidden rooms and exploring the place as so. The magic combat system and the magic system in general is you have to combine a certain combination of runes. You can find these combinations on scrolls which you find and by leveling up the certain types of skills in the game. Speaking of the skills, the skills are pretty much subclasses in classes. The 3 classes in this game are fighter, rouge and mage. (There's a fourth one too but you will have to discover that for yourself) Each class has different abilities, attributes, purposes, uses, etc. There's also traits you can have on each character. There's lots to choose from and some races have their own trait. The 4 races are Human, Minotaur, Lizardman and Insectoid. Each are good for their own class, like how the Lizardman makes a good rogue and how the minotaur makes a good fighter.Puzzle solving-The puzzles in this game are diffucult. I had a LONG time trying to solve them. But after solving all of them, it was all worth it since it was fun and rewarding.Exploration-Without exploration, I don't think this game would've been so great. There are TONS of secrets everywhere. Some are easy to find, some take forever to find. For all those loot lovers out there, you will love this game because of all the loot and what it takes to get it. To go into a little more depth of exploration is the moving system, to turn you can't just turn all the way around, to do that, you would have to turn sideways and look sideways again since you look always in a 90 degree angle.To conclude, I would love to say Legend of Grimrock is a great modern day game and I would recommend it to anyone.

content:
Posted: August 1, 2013
												For years I've been wanting to play a modernized old school first person dungeon crawl/RPGs. I tried going back and playing older ones like might and magic games but they just don't cut it over time. All I can say is Legend of Grimrock is EXACTLY what I've been waiting for. It takes all the fun, excitement, and strategy out of those old games and brings it to the current level of gameplay. It removes all the buggyness of older games, it replaces the confusingly blurred graphics where it's easy to miss an important item with beautiful design, poor puzzles with strategic challenges, choppy fighting with challenging battles, etc. I LOVED this game, I had so much fun playing it, and with the added function of a popular mod community and a dungeon editor it is really a top tier experience. If you like RPGs, or dungeon crawls, or have been craving what I have then look no further: this game is TONS of fun.

content:
Posted: April 15, 2012
												Grimrock... I have never had a game ever before take me back so very far into my gaming past. Way back, there was a game called Dungeon Master. It was the first adventure game I played, and this game replicates it perfectly in terms of gameplay. The game engine, the puzzles, everything about it just screams that this is one game that will take up a lot of your time.The gameplay itself is solid. You move on a grid, everything happens in real time, you have to eat, you sleep to regain health and mana, your torches burn out. So much management that most modern adventure games seem to miss, that add to the experience. The puzzles are well thought out, take effort to solve and are satisfying to get past. Combat is fast paced, requiring thought as well as a fast clicking finger.This is one game that remains true to the classic, old adventure games of gaming yore. Whether you remember that time or not, this is one experience not to be missed.

												I've been waiting for years for a game like this. Let's start with the fact that I'm a fan of "Eye of the Beholder"-like games. You know... these first person RPGs with the primitive movement (one button click, one square-step) where you never see the sun and you're wandering in underground mazes full of puzzles dealing with buttons,plates, teleporters and the like.The game has pretty good visuals, certainly good enough for this kind of game. But the thing it excels at is the puzzles. The creators have achieved just the perfect level of difficulty. Plenty of puzzles that are not easy enough (plague of modern games) but not too tough on the other hand to make you quit the game. You get the satisfaction of solving a puzzle without hitting your head on the wall (except for maybe a couple of cases :)), one of the cornerstones of great gameplay.Overall the game is great and cannot recommend it enough!  Just hope there were more games like this one

												Legend of Grimrock is one of a very small litter of games that attempts to create a classic dungeon crawler similar to those of the old days such as Dungeon Master and succeeds in not only emulating that style, but updating it enough to make it a refreshing experience for modern gamers, as well as a familiar one.A feature I found to be charming (as well as terrifying) was the option to play the game on a Classic difficulty that forces you to draw your own maps out on grid paper, much like old pen-and-paper tabletop games. I myself haven't been brave enough to give this playthrough a try yet, but I still find it to be a wonderful option for true gluttons of punishment.As deeply rewarding as it is challenging, with lots of replay value, and great Steam Workshop options to keep the game new for even the most frequent players, LoG is a for sure winner. I'll be eagerly awaiting the release of the second game, ready to brave the dangers between the dungeon walls once more.

content:
Posted: August 1, 2013
												For years I've been wanting to play a modernized old school first person dungeon crawl/RPGs. I tried going back and playing older ones like might and magic games but they just don't cut it over time. All I can say is Legend of Grimrock is EXACTLY what I've been waiting for. It takes all the fun, excitement, and strategy out of those old games and brings it to the current level of gameplay. It removes all the buggyness of older games, it replaces the confusingly blurred graphics where it's easy to miss an important item with beautiful design, poor puzzles with strategic challenges, choppy fighting with challenging battles, etc. I LOVED this game, I had so much fun playing it, and with the added function of a popular mod community and a dungeon editor it is really a top tier experience. If you like RPGs, or dungeon crawls, or have been craving what I have then look no further: this game is TONS of fun.

content:
Posted: April 15, 2012
												Grimrock... I have never had a game ever before take me back so very far into my gaming past. Way back, there was a game called Dungeon Master. It was the first adventure game I played, and this game replicates it perfectly in terms of gameplay. The game engine, the puzzles, everything about it just screams that this is one game that will take up a lot of your time.The gameplay itself is solid. You move on a grid, everything happens in real time, you have to eat, you sleep to regain health and mana, your torches burn out. So much management that most modern adventure games seem to miss, that add to the experience. The puzzles are well thought out, take effort to solve and are satisfying to get past. Combat is fast paced, requiring thought as well as a fast clicking finger.This is one game that remains true to the classic, old adventure games of gaming yore. Whether you remember that time or not, this is one experience not to be missed.

content:
Posted: September 11, 2013
												This right here.  Wizardry, Megami Tensei.  This is the future here.  Puzzles, exploration, a minimalist story, a creator's kit.  It's all good stuff.The Legend of Grimrock is a first person, real time dungeon RPG wherein you control a group of up to four prisoners dropped on the top of a dungeon mountain, given a trial by Tomb of Horrors.  You need to navigate through puzzles, traps and nopeworthy monsters, keeping in mind your placement and that of your enemies, the combinations needed for spells, the spaces in your inventory and much more to manage combat well.  It can be fast paced at times, and healing options are scarce between battles.  The environment and graphics are splendid, and while a bit short, it's cheap and offers a number of community made dungeons.  I dig it.

												A much longer game than expected.  Somehow I assumed it would be shorter since it has downloadable levels through Steamworks.I enjoyed playing it since it is a throw back to the original days of PC gaming and RPG's.  Took me about 17 hours to complete with breaks/getting lost.  I tried not to use any walkthroughs but I had to at the last area only to go... duh....The combat is slow pace to start but by floor 8 out of 13, you need to start being fast and moving around monsters or you'll die.  You can create your own team/race/class set up with four chars and create your own playstyle.  I had two tanks (sword/mace) and two mages (fire/earth).The downside is I started to get bored around floor 9, but decided to rush to the end and beat it.  Luckily floors 11-13 are somewhat qucik.  Cool if you dig old PC gamestyle, but most will likely be turned off by a game like this.

content:
Posted: September 12, 2014
												Giving a simple thumbs-up or thumbs-down to Legend of Grimrock seems to me to miss the point of the game; it was consciously designed for a very specific audience, and your enjoyment will depend upon your belonging to said audience. I'd describe Grimrock as a puzzle game with an RPG overlay. You're dumped on top of a mountain and have to fight and puzzle your way through a series of dungeon levels in order to get to the exit at the bottom. There's an opening graphic about being condemned to the maze and offered a slim chance at survival as punishment for unspecified crimes, like eating puppies or promoting Justin Bieber's music or somesuch. Unimportant; it's a reason for your four-person party to wind up stuck in a dungeon. Players of the Recent Might and Magic X: Legacy will find it has less involved, less tactically sophisticated combat but much tougher puzzles (it pains me to admit that I got stumped fairly early on); you look for a hidden switch that opens a door somewhere on the other end of the level that leads to a dead end with another switch disguised as a torch sconce that when pulled opens the gate you saw three turns back which leads to a scrap of paper with a password on it for that magical barrier you couldn't get past before...I've given Legend of Grimrock a thumbs-up because it seems to do what it set out to do: it provides a series of tougher and tougher dungeon puzzles for the player to obsess over, with some simple combat to leaven it. The game's a bit like extra-dark chocolate in that respect: people who already find it to their taste will love it, while people who don't will find it has a bitter, gritty flavour that sort of reminds them of something they like.

content:
Posted: April 12, 2012
												Summary:Grimrock is a first person (first party in this case) dungeon crawl.  If you've ever heard/played a game called Stonekeep (late 1990s), you'll enjoy this game too.  Well designed, immersive, and an absolutely beautiful sound track.  Some skill is required to be a magic caster / use magic in your party, but if you get good at it, you really feel you've earned the title "mage."Overall Score:  Worth Getting (Niche game)  -- ( 79/100)Gameplay:  (56/60 points)Mechanics (35/35 points) – rules/physics/noticeable glitchesI have never encountered any bugs while playing Grimrock.  The rules of the world fit very well with the challenges you face and you never feel like the game is cheating.Controls (8/10 points) – ease of operation / button dynamicsControls are very basic, left, right, back, forward, casting is difficult, but in a good way where you feel really good when you successfully cast a spell.  My only beef with the controls was inventory managment.  Trying to maintain 4 peoples inventory was very cumbersome at times.Difficulty ( 5/5 points) – how hard is it to progress & does this difficulty work for or against the playerThe game trains you as you go.  The first few levels are about learning how things work.  It's a good build up and by later in the game, it's about exploration, adapting and facing challenges that force you to use everything you've learned up to that point.Immersion ( 4/5 points) –  very subjective:  Being drawn into the gameThe environments are realistic enough and the sounds and music will make you forget about everything around you.  The desire to save as often as possible and searching for secrets areas and having to look up a few solutions was the only thing that broke immersion for me.Fun ( 3/5 points)– very subjective: other enjoyment factorsVERY fun, but not so fun that I actually finished the game.  It was still excellent though, I've gotten further into this game than most.Content:  (20/35 points)Story (13/15 points) – Does it exist, coherent, presentation of, and does it enhance game play?The opening was excellent, there's little scraps of papers and books that tell you more of the story thorugh the ponderings of a former "inmate."  Also every level of the game tells a different story and as you move further in, the very walls and status hint at darker things that have gone into the formation of Grimrock.  I can't say that the story is deep, but it is enjoyable. Characters (5/10 points) – Interesting, well developed, work with gameplay and storyThe characters are fairly standard fare for your Dungeons and Dragons -esque setting, but the manual had some great backstory on each.  It doesn't play into the game, but was good flavor text.“S.S.D.D.” value (2/10 points) – abilities, roles, tools, NPCs, and general world setting uniquenessVery typical for a dungeon crawl. Gamer Parent Factors:  (3/5 GOLDEN points)- (WIN) Ability to save / pause and come back later to pick it up right away again- (WIN) Ability to progress during short gameplay sessions (30 mins – 1.5 hours)- (WIN) Replay value and game length not related to required repetitive grinding to increase stats-  (NO)  Ability to play game with spouse or offspring-  (NO)  Availability on multiple platformsGamerDad Game Reviews -- Purpose and CriteriaThe purpose of GamerDad Game reviews is to evaluate ‘aged’ games that have been on the market long enough to experience a substantial price drop from their original industry standard price. Reviewing games towards the end of their life cycle will offer an updated consumer valuation of the game based on if known issues have been fixed since release, value of optional DLC (Downloadable Content made available after initial game release) to gameplay, and if the entertainment return on investment is worth the new price point.

content:
Posted: May 6, 2016
												A throwback game to old-school Dungeon Crawler RPGs, Legend of Grimrock easily succeeds at that, with a feature that, I feel, should’ve been in all those old-school Dungeon Crawlers of Yesteryear. It plays like one, it has absolutely no music, but rather, ambient sounds like none of them, it has hard fighting monsters like one, and in this review, that’s only scratching the surface. Let’s dig a bit deeper, and see what this game really offers.Gameplay: As mentioned earlier, Legend of Grimrock is a throwback to the old-school Dungeon Crawlers of the late 80s to the early 90s (or at least, I think that’s when these games were hot) and it succeeds at what it set out to do, too. It’s setting is that of Mount Grimrock, a large dungeon inside a mountain, and every bit of it is in first-person. The combat is somewhat fast-paced, but not so fast that you have to be faster than greased lightning to be able to get through fights. Their are helpful hints, if a bit obscure in places, that tell you how to proceed, and plenty of puzzles and traps to slog your way through. Story: The story in Legend of Grimrock feels a lot more fleshed-out than those games from which it takes its inspiration, such as the Dungeon Master games. Basically, though, the whole story amounts to this: you and your party members are prisoners convicted of an unknown crime, and you have been promised your freedom if you can escape from the dungeons of Mount Grimrock. Problems is, is that no one has ever managed to escape from Mount Grimrock, or at least, those who’ve been pardoned in this manner never have. It’s cliché, yes, but it works as a good driving force, because you’ll want to see what the King or whoever it is that sentenced your party to be pardoned in this way since you’ll inevitably be the first ones to ever escape this fate, right? But it actually goes deeper than that, because your party has dreams telling them of an original prisoner in the dungeon who knows the way out. I won’t say anymore on the story, because then I’d have to spoil it for you, and that wouldn’t be any fun, now would it?Music: As I said earlier, this game only has one particular song, and it only plays on the title screen. It’s pretty good, too!Graphics: The graphics look like about what you’d be expecting from a Dungeon Crawler that takes its inspiration from Dungeon Master, but with a modern day take on them. They look like graphics that you’d see in a modern day game.Now, that’s everything that’s in the game itself, but the game’s true strength really shines with the built-in Dungeon Editor. That’s right! Now you can make the Dungeon Master dungeons of your dreams with a bit more interactivity, thanks to Lua scripting and the Drag-and-Drop editing power of the Dungeon Editor for Legend of Grimrock.Overall, an amazing successor to the old-school Dungeon Crawlers of Yesteryear, Legend of Grimrock is an obvious success, and it’s one in which I hope you can escape the shackles that will undoubtedly hold you to it and keep you coming back for more!

content:
Posted: November 21, 2016
												Legend of Grimrock is a truly superb game, but certainly not for everyone. It is a beautiful, thoughtful, old-style dungeon crawler, very much reminiscent of Dungeon Master, Eye of the Beholder, etc for those old enough to remember them. It combines the thrill of continual discovery with the satisfaction (and occasional frustration) of interesting puzzles and bouts of combat. It thankfully brings the genre back from the 'choke on your loot' approach of the recent Adventure RPGs, making each find much more interesting than "is there an item here with purple text? No, into the bag of holding then". In fact this is typical of a game that is much more thoughtful, even though at times it can also be frantic and panicked. And so if this is the type of game for you, you will certainly be very pleased with it, and indeed also with Legend of Grimrock II which is even better in every way, and notably improves the character advancement and takes you outdoors.But there will be a few who find Grimrock flat, in particular the combat. It's not particularly tactical - more about understanding your best approach to combat than doing anything particularly tactical in combat itself, and there are many players who find themselves using an endless circle/strafing approach to combat which definitely works, but isn't much fun. These old hands don't have the reflexes for that, and likely that's a good thing, because facing up to combat (at least on most occasions) tends to be much more fun in the can-I-make-it kind of way!And each to their own, but if you have qualms about looking up puzzle solutions online when they start to get frustrating, Grimrock (and especially Grimrock II) could have it's downsides. That said, there will also be many moments when you pat yourself on the back for being smart, and there aren't that many games that do that any more.What's it worth? £20 / $25

												Yes, I know, it's a whiny statement, but let me kind of explain why I feel this way and perhaps it'll make more sense.I get the dungeon crawl concept. I've played them before, and roguelikes. Against all expectations, I beat the hardest of hardcore modes on Dungeons of Dredmor, I went through a couple playthroughs of Dark Souls, all that stuff. When I lose in those games, I feel it's because I did something to mess up, missed a move or made a wrong decision.With this game, there is no wrong decision to make, because no matter what you decide, you get thrown up against a difficulty spike that you can't possibly be ready for until you die at least once to it. If it isn't the obtuse puzzles that only make sense about half the time, it's the enemies that pop out of nowhere, can take forty times as many hits as any of your characters, and deal out damage that can kill you in seconds in a straight fight.I know a lot of people may disagree with this, and they certainly have a right to. But to me, this game isn't a challenge, or a dungeon crawl. It's just mashing my face against random walls in the hopes of finding a hidden switch, and getting killed a dozen times by the same overpowered monster group until I find the hidden cheese tactic that somehow lets me go down another floor.

												To make it short and sweet, this game can't decide what it wants to be. The base systems it sets up are sound, their levelling and RPG and class/team building mechanics are all solid and interesting.Then the combat throws all that out the window and makes you essentially try and play an FPS on a grid by circle strafing and dodging and such. There is little sense of type weaknesses, formation shuffling, tactical considerations, or any other interesting RPG type mechanics; just running around enemies and tapping the attack buttons until they die.This gets progressively worse throughout the game, with more and more "bullet sponge" enemies, until what might be the worst final boss fight I've had the displeasure to experience in a long time, in terms of lore, mechanics and comprehensibility.Maybe try that new Might and Magic game if you want an actual dungeon crawler, instead of a gridlocked FPS.

content:
Posted: September 18, 2016
												While I like the idea of dungeon crawlers Legend of Grimrock is simply too rough around the edges to recommend. At the time of writing this review I have completed the first three levels of the game with a Human Warrior, Minotaur Warrior, Human Rogue and Insectoid Mage party.Almost nothing is explained wellThe tutorial is a series of images that explain the most basic concepts of the game. The tooltips when you mouse over attributes or skills give you essentially flavour text. They don't really explain exactly what affects they will have which is a crucial part of RPGs like this where you really can't afford to waste points.I was constantly Googling trying to get clarification as to what exactly certain attributes or skills would do. A lot of times I got linked to the Steam forums where players seemed to be debating amongst themselves exactly what the affects were. The reason this irked me so much is that this is the prototypical old school RPG where you can easily spend points on stuff that is essentially useless and with no ability to respec it makes it really easy to make mistakes and which then feels like you have neutered your character.The combat is way too repetiveI'm about three hours in and so far the combat has essentially boiled down to right click on all four characters to have them take a swing, wait a couple seconds and repeat. There is no real strategy in how you attack, at least not yet.My melee classes have a weapon and a shield because it seems that high evasion is an absolute must for frontline fighters. However this means that they basically can do nothing except right click every couple seconds. Rogues in theory could have a bit of variety because you don't need a shield if your in the back row and could have two things equipped but the problem is that you can't attack with both. Any attack puts both equipped items on cooldown. This caries over to the mage who after they cast a spell has to wait again.For all of these reason combat becomes incredibly repetitive and boring. Perhaps it gets better later on and you get more ability to strategize but I am three hours into the game and it feels incredibly dumbed down to me. I'm sure some people reading this review are saying "you're suppose to move a lot in combat" and while I tried doing that it was no fun at all. Since you have to move on a grid it's essentially like chasing a younger sibling around the kitchen table. You can literally run in circles and the enemy can't hit you and while it is a valid strategy running around in circles for hours is by no means fun in my books.Old school grindingYou know how a lot of people talk about how games make "quality of life" improvements because developers realized that many of their game mechanics were simply there to elongage the time the user spent playing and actually really agitated the user? This game took all of those lessons and ignore them and instead went back to the old school Dungeons & Dragons mindset.Simple things like mages burn through their energy far faster than rogues or warriors so they become useless faster and require constant rest or trips to the life crystals to restore their energy.Health regenerates so slow that after a battle you often have to sit and wait to heal back up. Otherwise you're spending a couple minutes running back and forth between the afformentioned life crystals.Perhaps all of this wouldn't be an issue if the game dropped health or energy potions but in my three hours of playing I have only got enough ingredients to make four health potions and you will burn through them almost instantly.The straw the broke the camels back for me was the spiders on level 3. I had the best armor I could get at this point in the game as far as I am aware. Full light armor for both my warriors and they both had over 100 hp but the spiders would still hit for 20+. So I could take a max of three spiders back to back before my party was completely wiped and I had to take a couple minutes to properly heal.The kicker was that these spiders can poison you and of course poison means damage over time. Problem is the same ingredients you need to make health potions are the same ingredients you need to make antidotes and even if I made antidotes instead of health potions I would only have made four of them. I easily fought over 20 spiders and got poisoned over a dozen times. It would not have made any difference and I still would have had to run back to the life crystal a dozen times just to cure my poison because the game did not give out proper resources.In my mind these kind of games should be about battle strategy and how you use medicine during a battle is part of the strategy. But after four battles if you're completely tapped and the only strategy then is to cheese by running around the kitchen table well then I think that means something went wrong during the design of the game.Cool idea but bad executionLike I said in the first sentence of this review, I really like the idea behind this game. Crawling through a massive dungeon while overcoming the challenges inside. I just didn't think the challenges would be limited resources and knowledge of playing ring-a-round the rosie.

												The Legend of Grimrock is a fun and entertaining dungeon crawler role-playing game that really captures the core of the genre. Elements from Dungeons & Dragons and like games have been incorporated into the Legend of Grimrock and with great success. Coming from a person who normally doesn't like dungeon crawlers, this is definitely an amazing game! As if it could get any better, a dungeon editor is available, which allows players to build their own customizeable dungeons and share their creations with other players. This game contains many features for the player to explore and customize, as well as stimulating puzzles that can really boggle your mind. Although the puzzle aspect of the game pervades and dominates over the action or dialogue, the Legend of Grimrock is nevertheless an exciting RPG that revitalizes the dungeon crawler genre!

												I went into this game thinking it was a dungeon crawling RPG. It walks like one, quacks like one, and a whole lot of people seem to think it is one.This, however, is a Tomb Raider game. From the fixed item locations, to the limited use/high power dynamic of bombs, to mashing attack while jumping around like an idiot, to timed switch flipping, to the literal treasure hunting, to the inexplicable end boss, this is through-and-through a classic Tomb Raider game.Is it a good Tomb Raider game though? Eh, kinda. Better than Tomb Raider 3. Like Tomb Raider the game would be much improved by more complex movement options, but it still does most of what's possible in the limited vocabulary it offers. I was disappointed, but I did not feel my time was wasted.Note for laptop owners: thanks to a bug in the game's trackpad recognition several timed puzzles will be much harder than they need to be. They're still possible, but will require frame perfect accuracy.

content:
Posted: December 21, 2015
												I'm going to offer a dissenting opinion on this one, because it seems all the other grognards can't seem to take off their rose-tinted glasses and put on their real prescription lenses. Furthermore, this review is going to be different from most of the others, in that I'm going to focus on the controls. Read on and you'll see why.Essentially, this is the most awkward-controlling dungeon crawl I've ever played. It shouldn't be actively difficult to get my characters to do what I want. A lot of people defending the control scheme will say that this is how the old games played. Which old games, exactly, had controls like this? I played the old Wizardry. I played the old Might and Magic. I played the old Ultima. Those are the first in the CRPG genre, and they all managed to be much easier to handle than this. FFS, the old Wizardry games made you type out the spell names! No, scrambling to manage a UI during real-time combat doesn't simulate the rush of combat--it just serves to frustrate me. Having to click on a small area of the screen with speed and accuracy isn't nostalgic, since all the firsts of the genre didn't have mouse input. It's scientifically-proven bad design. Yes, there's real science behind it: it's called Fits's Law. Maybe if you're a twitch gamer you'll like this, but I just found it frustrating and tiresome.I grew up playing the firsts of the genre, and Grimrock doesn't resemble them at all--or if it does, I wasn't able to get to a point where I could appreciate it, because the controls are so bloody difficult. This game was an exercise in awkwardness and frustration that I haven't felt while gaming in a very long time. Don't confuse bad game design with challenge: the two are distinctly different.

content:
Posted: June 29, 2014
												I remember the first RPG I played on my very own first gaming system. The 8-bit NES. It was a dugeon crawler. The name was Swords & Serpents. It was a difficult one. With four different characters struggling through the mazes with only a few things in my mind. To level up, to find better equipment, to search for traps and secrets. Constantly threatened by wandering monsters, stronger every floor, and pay attention to traps and secrets every step you make for just that one bottle of potion extra, a few gold coins or that very nice piece of armor.Altough the genre was not so popular that moment but I enjoyed it a lot. I remember myself sitting in front of my big old TV with pen and paper to write down passwords en to map the maze. Many, many times the the devs try to make a RPG or dungeon crawler type of games to enjoy fighting monsters, hunting for treasure while exploring the dungeons. I enjoyed the Might and Magic series, but always after a few hours playing I can’t stand the graphics of that game. I think the game what reminds me most of my first experience was Wizardry 8. The graphics where great the moment from release (now still acceptable) and it was huge, with a lot of items, spells and exploring.When I saw the first screenshots of Legend of Grimrock I was hoping that this was a real modern version of my first experience. But I was skeptical. The graphics on the screenshots looked too good to be true. I thought that because of this beautiful graphics for sure the gameplay itself isn’t that good. I was disappointed a lot with modern versions of old games lately.With the SummerSales for I gave it a shot and after a few hours playing I’m blown away! It looks beautiful indeed. Even on my 3 year old laptop. The graphics are so polished and so smooth. I really like the style. Also stones are real stones with different width and height. That’s cool. No flat textures anymore. The lighting is fabulous. And the mouse freelook is very comfortable to inspect the first time you enter a room. That the rest of the movement is not free movement is only a good thing. It’s easy concentrate on the environment when walking around and you have time enough to inspect walls for loose stones to find secrets. I found A very balanced set of items for my first party in my first dungeon. If you want to reach the end you also need to use all your items carefully. Don’t throw away a little stone, take that +1 old armor and that shoes in the corner of the room. It can make the difference between more down one dungeon level or a single trip to hell.The monster movement is realistic and they look really good. The fighting is also very innovative, fast but fair. Just prepare yourself and click on the right time on your weapons to use them. It’s a little bit real-time and a little bit turn based. A good combination to keep you excited, but no need to be a master in keyboard combinations. The interface is totally friendly and slick.You can see the makers of this game are real interested in the genre and in my opinion deliver a great game for hardcore RPG, exploring, dungeon crawler, magic, fantasy, dungeons and dragons fans. But also a game what is very easy to learn, but hard to master, for the casual or newcoming gamers.What maybe for some people is one reason to consider is I didn't see too much of storytelling. Do not expect pages of information about things happens around you and history about the world you play in. There is not. For me that is not an issue. What you can expect is small notes with important information or text written on the walls. Even in the start of the game you have the possibility to not automap the game so you can go back to the good old days to make your own map! But it's optional.The character building as well isn't very complicated. It's the most basic skills and stats what you can have in game. But they are all there and it's very clear to see directly what effect the numbers have on different skills and stats.What is really make this game oustanding is the complexity of carefully exploring the level where you are in.Every move count, every choice of action you make count and for every single item it counts how, who and when you use it. That is gaming!I hope this game is give you the same great experience what I had with my first game in this genre.

content:
Posted: February 3, 2014
												Legend of Grimrock misleads the buyers to think it would be an oldschool dungeoncrawler. When in reality its a puzzlecrawler!Puzzle are chained after each other, so you get the feeling after some hours of playing, that if you manage to solve a puzzle, the reward is a puzzle, who would have guessed...It gets really boring, when you simply wanna crawl through a dungeon, but have to solve one thing after the other. Puzzles in general would be fine, but they're mostly just walking the wrong way until you find the right one. Rarely there are real puzzles to solve.There are some good things I can't deny, the game looks great and would be a real blast if it would be a real dungeoncrawler. A good thing is you can play the playermade dungeons. The original game though just gives me the feeling it was designed this way, to mislead the player into thinking the game had decent length. (really short)I bought the game at full prize, because of the overhyped reviews people give and the misleading promoting the makers give on their side, I quote directly from their website: " The ultimate dungeon crawling RPG", which isn't the case. (too short, nothing inovative, monster fighting is boring)Hope this helps someone, expect alot of puzzles! And by a lot, I mean a lot! If it's something you don't mind. Then feel free to buy it, its great if you like to play puzzle into puzzle into a bit dungeoncrawling into more puzzles.Atleast the Custom maps are worth a try!TLDR: 80% Puzzle 20% Dungeon, not the other way around! Misleading advertising! Wait for discount before buying or you may be dissappointed!Only a 5/10

												Lots of mixed feelings about Grimrock.  I had fun while playing it for sure, but the visuals are reptetitive, the interface is weird, and the controls are awful—trying to be cute and nostalgic by only allowing you to turn 90 degrees at a time.  But the worst part is that a game so full of secret buttons and levers and rooms requires you to find most of them.  This is a HARD game, and I can't imagine being able to complete it without finding a decent chunk of all of the tiny little hidden buttons in the walls, which means carefully inspecting every single surface of the dungeon, often with some sort of time requirement, or alt-tabbing to a guide (this one's awesome by the way: http://guides.gamepressure.com/legendofgrimrock/ ).  And that was fun and nostalgic for a while, but was incredibly tedious by the end.  (And even the Might and Magic games of more than 20 years ago didn't make me hunt for the pixel to click on.)

content:
Posted: March 15, 2014
												The most important thing to understand about this game is that it absolutely is not ... not ... an old-school RPG.  If you are looking for an old-school RPG this is not what you're looking for.  I would go so far as to say the suggestion that it is an old-school RPG is borderline false advertising.This is a puzzle game wrapped in the trappings of an old-school RPG, and played in real time rather than turn-based.  Combat is a dance puzzle with button mashing.  There are no tactics.  Magic is encumbered with rune selection, which must be done in real time, making casters a liability.  Rogues are just another combatant, there is no thieving.There is no story to speak of.  When you're not solving puzzles, you are seeking hidden buttons and pattern differences in wall tiles.Is it fun?  Yes, it's not bad as far as puzzle games go, nor is it anything special.  Yet, it's nothing but a puzzle game and that wasn't what I wanted.  I usually avoid Indie games, and now I will never buy an Indie game again.  I feel like I was conned, and robbed, and that this game has been intentionally marketed to fool old-school gamers for profit.

												I wanted to like this one. Really, I did. I'm all about old school RPGs, it comes with the Jim Sterling seal of approval, and I enjoy games that let me throw my own content in a bit, like with the portriats...That said, I couldn't do it. The combat is tiresome, tedious, and unrewarding. The interface is clunky and amatuerish. The bestiary is lifeless, the puzzels are unfulfilling, and worst of all, there's no dialog for all intents and purposes. This is as souless of a dungeon crawler as I've ever seen, devoid of wit, story, motivation, and wholly undeserving of the level of hype it's gotten. I can put up with it's old timey grid gimmick - maybe even enjoy the novelty some. But that's all that it brings to the table, and it isn't anywhere near enough. The interface needs a complete overhaul, the combat needs a lot of work, and for the love of Skyrim put some plot and dialog in! A straight up dungeon crawl can work, but you really need to frame it better - give me more of a world, give me context and a story. Give me details and motivation and reward me with more than a set of stairs and a big spoonful of the exact same thing I just did. I gave it a chance, and it isn't for me.

												This is like an updated and reimagined Dungeon Crawler like Dungeon Magic, Dungeon Master, Eye of the Beholder, or the Ravenloft PC games of the 90's. Simply brilliant game. Nice, catchy and pretty hardcore. The graphics, sounds and overall atmosphere in this game are so realistic, awesome, and just gives you chills because of the creepiness. The puzzles are very challenging, although it took a while to figure them out.  I got stuck like about 3 times, so i had to look at a playthrough video. This game is also very action packed, and it also can get scary, especially the screams of death. One night I played with my speakers turned up, the scream of death woke up my brothers wife and she came running to my room. When she opened the door,she saw a minotaur on my monitor, and screamed her lungs out as if she saw a ghost because her eyes couldnt take such epicness.  There are a lot of ways to die in Grimrock and if you're not paying attention, taking the time to search out better gear and learn to craft potions, you're going to have a difficult time with it. However, there's a great feeling of accomplishment as you traverse each floor, defeating powerful monsters and figuring out puzzle solutions on your own. I also like how this game has its own website and community, with people making mods, and helping out eachother. Definitely a game worth buying

content:
Posted: May 12, 2015
												The feel and presentation are superb but the actual game mechanics themselves leave much to be desired. By that I mean theres little depth to the RPG elements or they simply do not properly work. Playing a rogue for example, putting points into Missile weapons gains you Dex points, which affect your ability to hit in Melee, but not from a distance. Ranged attacks always hit something in front of you. Dex does not increase your damage with ranged atacks so by extension if you focus on using a bow for one of your characters, you'll build a stat that is nearly useless to them. This is by definition bad game design. Furthermore, I admire loot being hard to comeby, but not supporting all builds from the outset is dumb. If you're doing the above and making one of your characters an archer, then I hope to god you find the secret bow on level 3 or else you've been literally screwed. This is a game that should promote and reward exploration with better and special equipment but instead twists your arm into looking up secrets online to get the most basic of equipment.Overall, if you love the concept of this game then buy the sequel or stick to user made dungeons.

content:
Posted: March 31, 2014
												This game is simply not for me.  Why you ask?  Because I seem to solve puzzles differently than how the game developer intended in Legend of Grimrock.  The game itself is fairly good for a dungeon crawler, with decent graphics, simple gameplay, and not too demanding hardware specifications.  The game relies on solving a series of puzzles and finding things to advance to the next level.  The game is linear, and if you don't solve the problem in the exact manner intended by the game developer, you WILL BE STUCK, like I've been.The first time I time I played, I used a custom party of 1 fighter, 1 rogue, 2 mages, and I found the mages to be useless cheerleaders due to a lack of access to spells.  No problem.  Start a new game.  Second round of 2 fighters, 1 rogue, 1 mage seemed to be a better fit for the challenges awaiting me on level one.  However, there was a portion of the dungeon with 1 pit and 2 pressure plates, with snails waiting behind the gate.  I got past the pit with no trouble, and the gate lifted.  However, during the encounter I moved off the plate, and the gate slammed shut, with no way to lift.  From my previous playthrough with my abandoned party, I knew that this area was important in order to advance to the next stage.  With no way to lift the gate, I was stuck.  Thus, I needed to restart the level.Moving on to level 2, I almost cleared out the entire dungeon, if I could only find the two keys for the keyholes to the left and right out of gate, with a portal beckoning me to enter.  Unfortunately, I got stuck again.  Why? Because at the portion of the dungeon with two hidden rooms, I did not realize there was a second hidden room, with a key located there. I found 1 key in the room past the teleport trap, and used it.  When I retraced my step, I couldn't get the door to the second hidden room to open no matter how many times I pressed the hidden switch.  It appears that by using the key, I broke the script.  So now I've put five hours into the game, and I'm looking at the prospect of a third restart of the game.  Not worth it. :(

content:
Posted: October 30, 2015
												As an original fan of the Dungeon Master Series Legend of Grimrock held quite a bit of appeal for me. The game almost perfectly emulates  the gameplay of the classic series while bringing the visuals nicely up to date.GAMEPLAYSimilar to another Classic Series (Elder Scrolls), LoG casts you in the role of Prisoners being exiled for unknown reasons into the catacombs of Mount Grimrock. The focus of the gameplay is on combat and puzzle solving, the latter of which can sometimes be maddeningly frustrating, but very satisfying when you finally work it through.While you have complete freedom to go anywhere you want within the dungeon movement is grid based and fixed to the cardinal directions, up, down, left, right, and turning.  Some people (mostly new school gamers) find this limitation madden and arbitrary, but it plays an important role in gameplay and tactics.STORYThe story is there, but is very, very light. There are lots of little bits and pieces of info scatterd throughout (esp the story of former dungeon Denzien Toorum). You're ultimately left with more questions than answers, but you don't walk away feeling unsatisfied, and that's what the expanded Story in Grimrock 2 is for as well.In general if you are fan of or think you will enjoy the old grid based style then you'll like this game. But if you're not, pass

content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												Wizardry, Bards Tale, Dragon Wars, Eye of the Beholder... I have fond memories of all those games. The developers of "Legend of Grimrock" hoped to tap into that nostalgia with their new RPG, which updated the graphics but retained the retro gameplay. Unfortunately, they failed to take into account that there is a reason I don't play those games anymore: that retro gameplay sucks. Even back in the day, I hated the ridiculous maze-like levels and the "find the hidden button" puzzles, and looking for keys to open the next area is a trope so old that even Duke Nukem made fun of it. The combat is mildly entertaining, but - having long mastered the attack/strafe techniques in the early '90s - it lacks challenge. A distinct lack of variety in monsters and textures made it hard to maintain interest. I think I'll stick to more modern games in future.

Posted: November 14, 2013
												Legend of Grimrock is a dungeon crawling role playing game with an oldschool heart but a modern execution. A group of prisoners are sentenced to certain death by exiling them to the secluded Mount Grimrock for vile crimes they may or may not have committed. Unbeknownst to their captors, the mountain is riddled with ancient tunnels, dungeons and tombs built by crumbled civilizations long perished now. If they ever wish to see daylight again and reclaim their freedom the ragtag group of prisoners must form a team and descend through the mountain, level by level.The game brings back the oldschool challenge with highly tactical real-time combat and grid-based movement, devious hidden switches and secrets as well as deadly traps and horrible monsters. Legend of Grimrock puts an emphasis on puzzles and exploration and the wits and perception of the player are more important tools than even the sharpest of swords could be. And if you are a hardened dungeon crawling veteran and you crave an extra challenge, you can arm yourself with a stack of grid paper and turn on the Oldschool Mode which disables the luxury of the automap! Are you ready to venture forth and unravel the mysteries of Mount Grimrock?

content:
Posted: December 22, 2016
												This game is a convoluted mix of standard RPGs that permit free movement of characters and tactical strategy games that allow only limited and measured moves. Characters move jerkily in blocks in 4 possible directions -- front, back, left, right, the implications of which are severe: you can't move diagonally or look up and down; your characters cannot move by a distance of your choice since each keystroke takes it in any of the 4 directions only by a preset distance; you cannot have varying pace, i.e. your character cannot run or slow down; with this movement style, combat is bound to be weird and unenjoyable.This kind of jerky navigation system totally kills the charm of playing a fantasy RPG game by robbing you of the ability to set your own pace and enjoy the game environment by pausing anywhere you want to. This also creates problems during combat since you can look in ONLY 4 possible directions. The only way you can defeat an enemy is by sidestepping off its path and quickly circle behind him, and while you are going behind him you obviously cannot see what the enemy is doing and how it is positioning himself.This game is well-designed and I was looking forward to spending a week or so playing it. But the stupid gameplay has put me off. What should've been a simple and standard RPG affair has been reduced to a monkey dance.HORRIBLE.

												A well-done first person dungeon crawler, reminiscent of classic games such as the original Bard's Tale trilogy.  The graphics are well-done and the combat is fluid and engaging. Posted: January 11, 2014
												Pretty good dungeon crawler. I'm a big fan of the original Wizardry series (played 1, 2, 3, 7 and 8) and Eye of the Beholder (played 1 and 2). I miss those sorts of games, and Grimrock made me feel nostalgic, so I think it's a success.However, there were a couple things I didn't like very much. For me, much of the fun in RPGs and dungeon crawlers is the random loot, which comes in large part from random monsters. Every monster and item in Grimrock appears to be pre-placed. I think they did a fine job doing this, but any interest I may have had in replaying it with a different party has been eliminated by knowing that everything else about a second playthrough would be exactly the same. Maybe you'd like to have two characters wielding crossbows? Well, it seems you're out of luck. There appears to be only one crossbow in the game. You can't find another. There are also only a handful of quarrels -- about 20 I think. There are no vendors, so you can't buy/trade for more crossbows or quarrels. (Quarrels are reusable - you can pick them up again after the monster dies.)The other thing I like about party-based RPGs is exploring strategy. Particular combinations of buffs, debuffs, and attacks make combat richer and deeper, and reward you for taking time to think through your choices. Grimrock's combat, however, is mostly about dodging. There are very few buffs/debuffs, and it mostly doesn't make all that much difference what order your characters attack in. Which monster you attack first can make a difference, but mostly you won't be presented with much in the way of choice about that.In Wizardry 8, I started a brand-new game to explore a particular strategy. Rangers could get cricitical hits with ranged weapons, and gadgeteers could eventually learn to combine certain crossbows together so they could shoot three times per attack. Three rangers and a gadgeteer were hard in the early stages, and levelling up my gadgeteer and finding enough crossbows to equip each of my rangers with a triple-shot was a fun challenge. But once accomplished, my rangers were a rapid-fire killing posse, firing as many as 45 quarrels per combat round between them.  Buff them with speed, debuff the monsters with slowness and extra vulnerability to crits, and we weren't afraid of anything, especially if we could see it coming a long way off. The problem ended up being that it was awfully hard to carry around enough quarrels to get through more than a handful of fights. I had to take on some NPCs just to act as mules, and every trip to town involved clearing out every single vendor's stock of quarrels.We won't have any experiences like that in Grimrock, and that was disappointing to me.

Posted: July 26, 2014
												Legend of Grimrock takes me back to my old Eye of the Beholder days.  The game is great ... at first.The game starts great.  Allowing you to get used to everything before throwing you in to more difficult situations.  There are lots of tricks and secrets that hide items most people will want, but you won't find most without downloading maps and cheating.  The game continues to progress, level by level, harder and harder.  The puzzles also become harder and you find yourself, every now and then, having to lookup solutions.  But then everything falls apart at level 10.By the time you hit Level 10, you spend half your gaming time reading the tricks/secrets/cheats on how to continue to progress.  This is poor game design, in my opinion.  Fine, I don't get this weapon or this armor or that spell.  Let me progress!   But no, LoG doesn't do that.  Instead you are stuck in tricks, traps, puzzles, and more.  It's not the end of the world.  You can always look up the answers.  But then what's the point of playing this game?After several hours of having to lookup answers on Level 10, I decided it's time to shelve LoG.  It was a great game in the beginning, but fell off a cliff toward the end.  I don't care if they leave tons of puzzles and mysteries for people who want to try to figure them out to get some good booty.  But let me progress!  Let me continue the game without getting stuck and having to cheat to continue.  What's the point in playing this game then?-DD

Posted: December 23, 2013
												Not many modern RPGs can boast the presentation of a genuine challenge. Legend of Grimrock does, in mother♥♥♥♥ing spades. Thrown into a dark, dank, critter and/or zombie infested dungeon (the eponymous Grimrock), your four plucky prisoners must use any means at their disposal to escape from Grimrock, or, as is often the case, keep from becoming a stain on the rough-hewn cobblestone wall, while contending with the constant threat of hunger and/or giant venomous murder spiders.Every level was designed by hand; every trap, monster, mushroom, and weapon lovingly tucked exactly where it needed to be to make your experience as harrowingly awesome as possible. This is an old-school dungeon crawl through and through, and it'll never let you forget it. If you're, like me, too impatient and dense to check every nook and cranny for a secret cache of items, you won't see a longsword until you're 45 minutes in.The game has got some shortfalls, however. The tile-based movement means that it's pretty easy to take advantage of the enemy AI (something the rogue's assassination ability is built to take advantage of). Trolls, which are practically LoG's mascot and therfore built up as being incredibly badass, are kind of disappointing to fight because of this, since their charge attack (which they do whenever you're at least one tile away from them) leaves them wide open for a backstab. They will, however, give you a thundering ♥♥♥♥♥-slap for your trouble if you try to dance around them as per usual. The puzzles can somethimes get a little frustrating, too, if you're used to having more than a cryptic, vague line of text to go on.Overall, it's pretty great, and triumphing over an army of poisonous ents and badass,♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥off mudcrabs makes you feel awesome like few other things can.

Posted: May 25, 2013
												Legend of Grimrock is an old-school RPG that harkens back to old first-person dungeon crawlers such as the venerable Eye of the Beholder series, the older Might and Magics or the Wizardry series.My first playthrough on normal difficulty took close to 20 hours and this was considering that i had skipped a couple of puzzles and also had to consult the net for solutions to some of them.Puzzles are the core of the game. Some of them are essential for game progression, most are optional, and ALL of them are very cleverly crafted and are absolutely fun and challenging. You will definitely get a sense of satisfaction if you manage to solve it without any help.However because of this, I personally felt that the game focused too much on puzzle solving, and the game sometimes felt more like a puzzle game with RPG elements instead of an RPG with puzzles.Instead of having puzzles subtly presented like in the old Eye of the Beholder series, Grimrock literally hands you a puzzle room and even puts out a label of the puzzle's name.On the whole, this makes the whole game feel more like 13 levels of puzzle rooms where you just need to solve it to progress instead of an RPG with a coherent story that gives context to the puzzles.Story is definitely not Grimrock's strong point, and it only provides an introductory excuse to let the player know why he is in a dungeon. As a game touted as an RPG, the treasure and loot selection are unfortunately not exciting. There are only a couple of limited choices. This game also features the most rediculous looking final boss in an RPG ever.Music is very well done and sounds appropriately cinematic and epic. However, there are only 2 tracks in the whole game. The art style while looking very modern, recycles alot of textures and makes every dungeon level feel the same as the earlier ones.The main gripe I had was the magic system, which was overly complicated and too frustrating to use. It actually requires you to remember spell combinations and click on them fast during battle. I felt that they should have had a simpler approach to this, or at least provide a simpler alternative style. (Eg: why can't we right click on the mage's hand, choose the spell i want and just cast it?)Despite its flaws, Legend of Grimrock is still a very good game and is a worthy addition to the past glorious dungeon-crawlers. The fact that the entire game was made by only a 4 man team with a limited budget really blows the mind. Whats more, they even allowed player modding on this game which is probably a first time for games of this type and genre.For veterans of old-school RPG dungeon-crawlers, this game is a definite must buy. For newer gamers who have never experienced such old-school gameplay before however, it is better to review the gameplay videos before deciding if this game is for you. The play style in this game may not appeal to modern gamers.Overall Rating: 8.0 / 10An excellent and authentic old-school dungeon crawler that veterans would enjoy. I cannot wait to see a sequel to this game. Two thumbs up. Don't miss it.

Posted: April 18, 2012
												Old-school dungeon-crawlers have been making a comeback the last few years, and this doesn't disappoint.  Grimrock takes players and tosses them into a labyrinthian underground rife with puzzles and secrets to conquer, while roaming monsters are happy to startle you from the dark corners and shadowy distance.  With no music playing in the background, you are thrown into a place with heavy atmosphere: small sounds tickle the ears while monsters are heard shuffling about, and faint whispers make you wonder if you're actually alone down here..or if you're going mad from the oppressive isolation.  With a team of four, three job classes to choose from, and a variety of builds to utilize, the game is quite balanced and rewards those with quick reflexes as battles are done in real-time.  Those who stay alert and take in details with scrutiny will be rewarded as well, as buttons hidden in stone can be easily missed.  Be patient, cautious, and cunning..and you may find freedom from the dark.
