Posted: March 13, 2016
												Well, as you can see from the playtime I've put a lot of hours into this game.  I was a huge huge fan of Dungeon Master, then Chaos Strikes Back, and of course the Eye of the Beholder series.  I even tried my hardest to like StoneKeep, but it was just a touch too formulaic to be considered an 'evolution'.. It was really just a repetition.   At the time, the Bards Tale games were also exploring the rectilinear 2.5D game approach, and I did quite like them, but they were vastly inferior at projecting an atmosphere (I felt).    So, I hope you get an idea of where my review is coming from: I'm a die-hard Dungeon Master fan, who really likes the genre, but is looking for DM with improvemetns.Legend of Grimrock is a superb game, there is no doubt about it.  "Polised" doesn't even come close to explaining just how wonderful the world is.  The rocks glisten, the toches flicker, and everything has the exact same 'feel' as Dungeon master, from the pressure-plates, and doors opening to the 'worms' (now snails) which offer up repulsive-sounding chunks of meat to keep your party alive.   The big question that you want to ask is "Does it represent 25 years of advancement over Dungeon Master?".  The answer is "mostly".  I'll explain in a bit more detail...The game is effectively the same as Dungeon Master: You start out at the 'top' of a dungeon. In DM, you were a party of resurrected adventurers controlled by a wizard (who you could see if you battled your way all the way back up the dungeon and used the 'see through walls' spell on the first door!).  In LoG, you're a party of four adventurers, imprisoned for unknown reasons in a big mountain.   The door closes, and this is where the first main difference arises: Choosing your party.In DM, you 'floated about' as a spirit essence, looking at paintings of dead adventurers, choosing who to resurrect, and who to 'take' but remould into your desires.  This was completely revolutionary.  LoG picks a very AD&D approach instead, and just allows you to stat-roll and custom-build your party.   DM allowed you a lot of freedom over your party. It was pretty much possible to get anywhere and do anything with any party (although a lone adventurer was too hard for me to ever complete the game with).  LoG is essentially the same, however there are some classes which are completely useless, and some races which appear to be awesome (minotaur).  I took a Rogue, but didn't look at the achievements list, so never got assassination, and therefore never got the one thing that the rogue is good for, the backstab Steam Achievement. Pah.OKay, so you pick your formulaic team (Fighters up front, mage(s) and rogue(s) up the back), and head into the dungeon.   The first level is a training level, as you'd expect. You're deposited naked, so you find some loincloths, daggers and rocks, and use them to bludgeon the locals, as you'd expect...  There are a few traps, and puzzles, but by and large, it's your standard training level.  HOWEVER, the game's true nature comes to the fore at this point...The training level can kill you.  And is does. Over and over.  You see, there's a trick to playing LoG, which you have to learn RIGHT at the beginning, or you're going to die. and die. and die.  You must never try to go toe-to-toe with an enemy. You will die.   The monsters are always scaled to be a difficult challenge.  To fight you must find at LEAST a 2x2 grid, and strafe, rotate, hit, strafe, rotate, hit, strafe, rotate, hit... and so on.. and so on.. until one of you is dead.    Woe betide you if there are two enemies: This is a retilinear circus of death.. you'll get trapped, and die.  For two enemies, you need a 3x3 grid, making sure never to step into a corner cell if you can help it!  And so, you quickly learn the mathematics of LoG.  Quick count: 3 enemies, right I'll need a 4x4 space to dodge around them in, at least.If you're REALLY lucky, you'll come across them in a snake-like corridor, and can use their abysmal path finding against them.  Monsters will often sidestep with you, so you can pop-left, shoot, pop-right, and the monster will take the arrow or fireball in the face, then step right again, and now there's some rock between you.. You wait to cooldown, and rinse repeat.I'll say this again: Never ever ever try to go toe-to-toe with an enemy.  Sometimes you can't help it. In this case, you're probably boned, but try and slash your way out of it as best you can:  There are some 'secrets' which FORCE you to be in the middle of a swarm of things (Fighter's Challenge), and in this case, you're boned.  Over and over.. until you get lucky and reload enough times that a space randomly appears in front of you, or whatever, and you're able to retreat out of the swarm... Something like that..Supplies are in short supply:  Lack of food is the main impetus to keep moving.  There were many times that my party were getting low, because I'd been searching for secrets, and I just had to plough on into the next level, to get some food.    At first I found it annoying: Cosntantly running low: There are penalties for being hungry!  But then I realised it was to stop people stagnating on earlier levels.   I remember in DM having my entire party encumbered with Worm Rounds because we'd camped near a spawn point, and I ended up dagging them up and down, and up and down, three or four levels down from the spawn point, so I could have a stash.   Similar things happen in LoG. There's a famous 'snail room', but you only get two snails, which is barely enough to keep two party members alive.  However, they do replenish every time you step a certain distance from the room...As you get deeper and deeper, the enemies stay just as hard.  Okay, I KNOW they're getting harder, but I'm getting better at the same pace.  So, while a snail on level one needs ten dagger-hits, a cthulu-faced magic-wielding lightning-thrower-evil-demon on Level 12 still takes ten lightning-sword hits.   So, the 'experience' changes a little with the variety of ranged vs. melee monsters, but the game stays uniformly difficult.  In DM, there definitely felt to be an advancement in ability, and monsters became easier.. So in DM, that demon would take three lightning-sword hits, if you see what I mean?Descending through LoG, the 'tunnels' feel slightly different. You start off in fairly rustic 'sewers'?, and then descent into perfectly rectilinear dressed-stone corridors.  They stay this way until the very last level, which goes very industrial, and it becomes clear what the game's emblem is all about.There's a LOT of side-activity here.  You can plough through without finding many secrets, but the majority of the good stuff is behind tiny buttons, and so on, so it really pays to explore.   However, there's always that looming hunger, so you can't spend too long.  There's about enough surplus food int he dungeon (without snail-mining), to get you back to Level 1 from Level 12 two or three times, if you forgot something, before you really start to run dangerously low.I'd say my main gripe about this game is the w ay that the skill 'trees' (or just skill List) works.  In DM, you started off beign able to do "14", (fire), and then learned "144" (fireball)... But once you leveled up, you could try for "244", bigger fireball... sometimes it'd work, sometimes it wouldn't.   LoG has nothing like this.     My second main gripe is that magic needs SO MANY DAMNED CLICKS to work.   five perfectly-placed clicks on smal squares, while you're trying to strafe,turn,hit,strafe.... is a REAL pain the a$$!!!!   All in all, I'd say this was a really excellent attempt to remake Dungeon Master.   They've missed some of the fun in a few areas, and instead concentrated on graphical beauty.  Doesn't stop me from recommending this though. It's a great game, so long as you learn the one cardinal rule: Do not go toe-to-toe with an enemy if you can help it!

Posted: December 21, 2014
												Initially I voted Not Recommended for this game. Now that I've played Legend of Grimrock through, I decided to change my vote to Recommended with some qualification. There is a great deal to love about LoG. I only wish the developers had reconsidered a couple of design decisions. Understand that LoG is a dungeon-crawler not truly an RPG. There is no role-playing and very little story. The only RPG elements are that you can generate your own party and determine your characters stats as they level. You interact with no other characters and converse with no one, not even your own party members. Where LoG succeeds is in its retro style and feel, but with contemporary high-quality graphics. Additionally, LoG has plenty of difficult battles, many fun and intriguing puzzles, and considerable switch-hunting (be warned). LoG is not a turn-based game as you might expect for an RPG; it's real-time. Depending on your expectations and playing style, this feature can be annoying or thrilling, because monsters can attack you unexpectedly as you view your map, manage your inventory, or even as you level up. I loved this aspect of the game.Be aware, though, that if you have only average manual dexterity, the game can at times become very frustrating as you load, reload, ad nauseum, trying to "solve" running/timing puzzles that occur in the game. A couple of these puzzles can be bypassed, but then you will miss some of the game's most coveted items. A few are required to progress, however, and these can be game-stoppers. Worse, the movement system is not really geared to running/timing puzzles because you move one square at a time, and it's quite easy to overrun your mark--yet these puzzles require precise timing without any room for error. I found it irksome that I could understand a puzzle, but couldn't "solve" it because my fingers weren't fast enough. This dimension of the game made little sense to me; after all, the game purports to be a dungeon CRAWLER, and this genre traditionally relies on wit, thought, and tactics, not rapid finger movements like a platform game. I finally was able to deal with the two worst of these puzzles. For one of them, I found an AutoHotKey script that with minor adjustments did the work for me; for the second, inspired by the script just mentioned, I developed my own AutoHotKey script. That was more challenging and satisfying than endlessly retrying a puzzle my fingers just wouldn't do.In another odd design choice, the developers required some commonplace items to solve a puzzle essential to progress in the game, but then didn't include the items on that level. These were the kind of items players might have easily ditched as useless levels earlier. Being compelled to trudge back several levels to search for discarded items is not fun. Fortunately, you can use the LoG console to generate the items if you don't want to bother backtracking levels.Still, once you get beyond these issues, Legend of Grimrock is an enthralling game. If you're new to dungeon crawlers, don't expect something with the strong character interaction, huge world, and depth of story of, say, Dragon Age. That's not what Legend of Grimrock is about. But if the idea appeals to you of a dungeon-crawler/puzzler with heaps of combat, secrets, and wicked traps, go for it. You'll love Legend of Grimrock.

Posted: November 11, 2015
												Fantastic game to play, with well thought out content.However, I wish some aspects would be rethought/removed. For instance, the Spiders, completely OP with the poisoning. Rapid attack with a high chance of poisoning, even when equipped with poison resistance. That's all well and good, if you have a never ending supply of Anti-venom potions. These are easy enough to make, using only one herb and a refundable bottle. From the moment I started up until the first spider encounter I saved the herb to make the Anti-venom, which lasted me a good 8/9 poisonings. Considering the front two party members can both be poisoned, on the same attack, you burn through the potions incredibly fast. That wouldn't be a problem had they made the herb a common find. You just end up having to run back to the Crystal every time you are poisoned, or waiting it out, sleeping, until it wears off. What is the point in the potion, if it only lasts you 5/6 spider encounters, and then your running back and fourth just to remove poisoning? Pointless, in my opinion, it just makes the game incredibly boring.What should be done with the potion is that it gives you poison immunity for a set amount of time. That way you wouldn't burn through every potion to the point you are using the Crystal to remove poison.It's just a bad aspect of the game, in my opinion.Other than that it is fantastic. Great little puzzles, although stupidly easy. I recommend this to any RPG lover. I would say it is aimed more towards old D&D players, or people that don't mind movement and fighting restrictions.

												Pretty good game overall. Probably about 18 hours straight out from beginning to end and it never really became monotonous. I haven't played a dungeon crawler like this in over a decade so I don't really have a good rule of measure as to how good the good parts are.The upsides are: the puzzle system, basic loot system that isn't way over the top like most white washed rpgs(getting a sword is a big deal), finding secrets and the multiflloor nature of the dungeons(falling down holes to find secrets), the logistics system(food, rest, potions)The downsides are: a poor magic system(clicking runes instead of casting spells with one click makes having more than one mage a pain), the lack of integration between party members in combat e.g. Ogre Battle 64 has a combat system with more depth and it uses pretty much the same frontline tank back line nuke system; no comboing off your mages.The battle system is pretty basic: click and swipe and kite around in a sqaure; use your mage nuke to pull.I played with an insectoid warrior and minotaur warrior in front row and a human rogue and insectoid mage(poison) in back row. Rogue had 12 points in assassination so it could attack from back row with daggers.If the mages casting system was better I would do another play through but as is I don't feel like manually clicking runes over and over in the middle of battle.If you play fps a fair amount it is a good idea to remap the strafe and turn keys.

There's something curiously, immensely satisfying about finding a secret, or figuring out how to crack open the lucrative iron door'd treasure rooms, or deciphering a cryptic riddle scroll. Considering the front two party members can both be poisoned, on the same attack, you burn through the potions incredibly fast. That wouldn't be a problem had they made the herb a common find. You just end up having to run back to the Crystal every time you are poisoned, or waiting it out, sleeping, until it wears off. What is the point in the potion, if it only lasts you 5/6 spider encounters, and then your running back and fourth just to remove poisoning? Pointless, in my opinion, it just makes the game incredibly boring.What should be done with the potion is that it gives you poison immunity for a set amount of time. That way you wouldn't burn through every potion to the point you are using the Crystal to remove poison.It's just a bad aspect of the game, in my opinion.Other than that it is fantastic. Great little puzzles, although stupidly easy. I recommend this to any RPG lover. I would say it is aimed more towards old D&D players, or people that don't mind movement and fighting restrictions.

												Pretty good game overall. Probably about 18 hours straight out from beginning to end and it never really became monotonous. I haven't played a dungeon crawler like this in over a decade so I don't really have a good rule of measure as to how good the good parts are.The upsides are: the puzzle system, basic loot system that isn't way over the top like most white washed rpgs(getting a sword is a big deal), finding secrets and the multiflloor nature of the dungeons(falling down holes to find secrets), the logistics system(food, rest, potions)The downsides are: a poor magic system(clicking runes instead of casting spells with one click makes having more than one mage a pain), the lack of integration between party members in combat e.g. Ogre Battle 64 has a combat system with more depth and it uses pretty much the same frontline tank back line nuke system; no comboing off your mages.The battle system is pretty basic: click and swipe and kite around in a sqaure; use your mage nuke to pull.I played with an insectoid warrior and minotaur warrior in front row and a human rogue and insectoid mage(poison) in back row. Rogue had 12 points in assassination so it could attack from back row with daggers.If the mages casting system was better I would do another play through but as is I don't feel like manually clicking runes over and over in the middle of battle.If you play fps a fair amount it is a good idea to remap the strafe and turn keys.

												A beautiful love-letter to the Dungeon Crawlers of the 1970's and 80's.Smart. Beautiful.Tough, but fair.The game is PACKED with secrets, secrets, secrets and you are constantly keeping an eye on your food meter since resting while starving does you no good. The game is well-balanced but does NOT hold your hand-- this is not for your little sister to play, even on normal difficulty.Walking on a grid system took some getting used to, but the game is well-paced enough that by the time it hits its stride you're a master at it. The game is going to give your the best experience during the FIRST playthrough only, though. As it is a puzzle game at heart-- the puzzles don't change. Going back through a second or third time would only be for the over-achievers that want to find all the secrets, hidden items, skulls (yes skulls), treasures and so on. I got 22/40 achievements just playing it through the first time. I only had to look up the solution to two puzzles in the entire 20hrs of gameplay, and felt halway clever the rest of the time. The game does a good job of coyly telling you what to look for, then letting you walk RIGHT past it soon after and NOT getting that cool sword that's hidden in the walls.Be patient, Be smart, Be methodical. Grimrock IS out to get you. Food is scarce and some enemies are a bit overpowered--- again, tough but fair. You'll have a blast wandering down its tunnels. I wholly recommend it. 9/10

Posted: December 3, 2014
												Tribute to oldschool games. And an awesome one.Legend of Grimrock is a dungeon crawling game with puzzles. For start, let me say I usually don't like puzzle games.In LoG, you get to create your party (nice races, classes, names, you know it) which you are leveling up throughout the game. It's fun, especially the difference between classes (Mage is the most powerful but useless without mana and can get killed quickly while Rogue is also weak but comes with interesting tricks) and positions. Yes, you heard right, positions. You'll figure that out. The casting system is also nice, although hard to remember sometimes (take that as a challenge!). The puzzles themselves are nice and easy, but getting harder while you're progressing. I never really found a puzzle I couldn't solve, except one, but as I found out that was because I missed a hint somewhere earlier in the game. The dungeons are nicely designed and so are the traps and monsters - who are really original and (unfortunately for me, got stuck and the end of the game, gotta try a new party I guess) deadly. The game, while being oldschool, has a modern execution so it plays rather smoothly and the graphics are nice. Furthermore, it comes with easy to learn editor! To dungeons, adventurer!

There are lots of tricks and secrets that hide items most people will want, but you won't find most without downloading maps and cheating.  The game continues to progress, level by level, harder and harder.  The puzzles also become harder and you find yourself, every now and then, having to lookup solutions.  But then everything falls apart at level 10.By the time you hit Level 10, you spend half your gaming time reading the tricks/secrets/cheats on how to continue to progress.  This is poor game design, in my opinion.  Fine, I don't get this weapon or this armor or that spell.  Let me progress!   But no, LoG doesn't do that.  Instead you are stuck in tricks, traps, puzzles, and more.  It's not the end of the world.  You can always look up the answers.  But then what's the point of playing this game?After several hours of having to lookup answers on Level 10, I decided it's time to shelve LoG.  It was a great game in the beginning, but fell off a cliff toward the end.  I don't care if they leave tons of puzzles and mysteries for people who want to try to figure them out to get some good booty.  But let me progress!  Let me continue the game without getting stuck and having to cheat to continue.  What's the point in playing this game then?-DD

Posted: October 15, 2014
												Legend Of Grimrock is one of my favorite games released over the last couple of years, and hands-down the best from an indie developer. People call it "the game that revived the dungeon-crawling genre", and this couldn't be more accurate in my case.I grew up playing Lands Of Lore: The Throne Of Chaos. A similar, two dimensional, tile-sliding real time fantasy rpg. Nothing could top it, and Grimrock brought me something I had always hoped for: a modern re-imagining of this style of game.Having played through the regular game twice, and trying out a number of the great user-created content packs, this game has almost everything I'd want. A great variety of gameplay challenges and obstacles, gorgeous graphics, captivating atmosphere and story, tons of danger. Plenty of challenge is present, as well as an easy means of scaling difficulty to one's personal preference. Additionally, the custom dungeon workshop has provided an easy way for creative fans to build using the game's engine very easily and intuitively. There are some mods that even top the core game itself!While I recognize that Grimrock's appeal is somewhat niche, those who aren't addicted to first-person games, have patience for difficult combat, and enjoy the challenge of a dungeon delve with many survival elements like light sources, food management, and mapping your environment will undoubtedly find this interesting, if not fantastic. The only criticism I can think of is wishing for character voicing and enlarging the world/taking the game outside of a subterranean environment at least some of the time.Thankfully, Grimrock 2 is being released in...ten minutes as of writing this, and promises to do the latter. This game is a modern classic and will always be on the tip of my tongue. It's a thrilling and refreshing experience in the world of modern gaming. I challenge you to take your first step...

												This game has the feel of and old school dungeon crawl RPG updated with modern graphics.  One of the most refreshing aspects of the game is just how simple it is. Posted: June 29, 2014
												Legend of Grimrock is a close descendant of games some older audiences might remember fondly. Remember Lands of Lore? Add 3D graphics, remove open world locations and stick to one huge tower, trade puzzles with items for strange riddles and timing your actions in order to get to places, give some sort of customization over your characters while promoting a specific gameplay and...It's really hard to say anything about Legends of Grimrock without making a reference to the past. The reason is that there is no single word to explain the genre (and no, it's not "adventure" or "RPG" that I'm talking about) of exploring dungeons on what is essentially a top-down map as a party of four while collecting junk and treasures, just for the sake of reaching the end.It's not hard to say, however, that the game (which I'm not too proud to admit I haven't completed... yet) has some nasty balance issues, in my opinion. Some of the creatures you encounter are ludicrously powerful and it's not like they have a specific weakness other than being attacked with all that you've got. There's also the thing about some of the timing puzzles requiring you to not move the camera as you move in order to avoid losing precious seconds which, ultimately, make you fail the puzzle with varying consequences.A plus side? Workshop integration. You can create your own custom levels and play them. You can play custom levels other people have created. And for what it is, Legend of Grimrock had the balls to finally return to something we all loved in days now hazy and somewhat succeeded in capturing a big chunk of its essence.Should you buy the game? If you haven't already, either from a promotion or bundle, sure. The price seems a little steep for what is most likely a love-it-or-hate-it entry, so definitely get it at a discount.

Posted: March 12
												It's a decent game, and a good recreation of old grid-based dungeon crawlers.THE GOOD:- Great graphics and runs fairly well for such a low-budget game- Quick saving/loading in an era of Halo checkpoints- Dungeon editor is included- A few old tropes are averted to interesting effect: the game is now real time, you have front- and back-row teammates, you can game traps to a certain extentHowever, there are some design flaws.THE BAD:- Character progression is very shallow and rather trite: basically you pick a weapons skill and then circle strafe enemies while hunting for secret gear with very little other thought into builds- There is practically no music other than the theme song (which, nonetheless, is great)- The interface was like a touchscreen game, although the game was ported to iOS 3 (!) years after its PC release. What I mean is there is a distinct lack of hot buttons, everything depends on a mouse click, and this can be very annoying especially later on with faster enemies.- The final boss is just ridiculous, taking the real-time aversion to its limit in a way that I'm sure you don't want to deal with, whoever you are, even if you enjoy action games.- The amount of button-hunting required to even reach that point is also ridiculous, and be prepared to either backtrack repeatedly or look up a walkthrough to get through the game.Depending on what you think of the above, make the decision for yourself. Since Steam, for some reason, is forcing me to give me a blue glowy thumb of happiness or red festering thumb of hate for the game, I'll give a blue.

Posted: November 30, 2014
												A beautiful love-letter to the Dungeon Crawlers of the 1970's and 80's.Smart. Beautiful.Tough, but fair.The game is PACKED with secrets, secrets, secrets and you are constantly keeping an eye on your food meter since resting while starving does you no good. The game is well-balanced but does NOT hold your hand-- this is not for your little sister to play, even on normal difficulty.Walking on a grid system took some getting used to, but the game is well-paced enough that by the time it hits its stride you're a master at it. The game is going to give your the best experience during the FIRST playthrough only, though. As it is a puzzle game at heart-- the puzzles don't change. Going back through a second or third time would only be for the over-achievers that want to find all the secrets, hidden items, skulls (yes skulls), treasures and so on. I got 22/40 achievements just playing it through the first time. I only had to look up the solution to two puzzles in the entire 20hrs of gameplay, and felt halway clever the rest of the time. The game does a good job of coyly telling you what to look for, then letting you walk RIGHT past it soon after and NOT getting that cool sword that's hidden in the walls.Be patient, Be smart, Be methodical. Grimrock IS out to get you. Food is scarce and some enemies are a bit overpowered--- again, tough but fair. You'll have a blast wandering down its tunnels. I wholly recommend it. 9/10

												The screensaver of gears alone is probably worth half the price of this game. Actually its not a screensaver, but that would be awesome if it was!There's something appealing to me about old-school dungeon crawlers and Legend of Grimrock is no exception.Creating your party = winExploring dungeons = winGaining experience/levels = winFinding treasure = winSpooky factor = winNot too difficult puzzles = winSmooth and Steady gradation of difficulty = winWhat separates this first person dungeon crawler is the whiff of dry humor and psychedelics (your party will eat their share of mushrooms to stay alive). And the reason I say that is because of how smooth the gradation of difficulty/monsters/puzzles goes as your progress.One thing I find difficult however, is spellcasting in combat. It can be challenging to manage 4 characters in real time combat much less managing the spells of the caster. You actually have to click on a recipe or sequence of 3 symbols to cast spell. A party of spellcasters? Unthinkable. Out of the question. Impossible.And here's my solution: HOTKEYS! Why cant we use hot keys to program our top 3-5 used spells?Backpack/Weight management can also be difficult. I took one minotar in my party and his worth in packmule and tank roles was quickly surpassed by my human fighter of average abilities save for SKILLED Feat +5 skill points. She actually has almost as many hit points as my minotar, easts less food, has higher armor rating, higher weapon rating, much more reliable.All in all 4/5 looking forward to the Legend of Grimrock 2 after I beat this one.

Posted: November 17, 2014
												Legend of Grimrock game review pending… (maybe forever…)  Okay, a quickie…  The game is freaking awesome!  Great old school RPG gameplay, party of 4, awesome graphics, lighting and sound, etc, etc…  Buy it!!!  Also know that Legend of Grimrock 2 is also out and you may want to get that.  I have a Mac running OS X 10.6.8.  See bottom for my full specs.The Legend of Grimrock (LoG) "Level Editor" alone is worth the price of the game!  I seriously may never play another game accept for my own LoG adventures!  I am so addicted to this editor and pretty good at it too if I might say!Seriously, I cannot break away from the level editor long enough to write a review about the game which is also really awesome!  Ideas just keep popping into my head for my adventure.  The editor is the easiest, most powerful game editor I have ever used.  An 8 y/o could make full blown D&D style adventures!  It's that easy. I never once needed a manual except when scripting a couple of things.  There is good support on their website for that.  There are scripting abilities using the included Lua scripting language, but know that you "do not" need to use scripts at all to create full blown adventures with stories included, if you want to write them on walls! :-)  I used Lua to write messages on screen, instead of walls.  Say, sometimes you want to set the mood with some text as you enter a room…  You can easily place an invisible switch on the floor and link it to some scripted text.  I only needed scripting so my text would show up on the HUD.  If you want text on walls, it is much easier!  You basically set a text box on a wall and type what you want it to say.  It shows up on the wall as a golden unfamiliar text.  Kind of like the old "Lord British's Ultima textstyle".  Then you click on it to read it.You can easily insert short or long text onto walls to create a story if you want, or to leave cryptic messages for puzzles you can create.  I believe anything that is done in the game, can be done with this editor.  If you like to build maps and levels with a D&D type theme, do not hesitate to get this game.You'll be so proud of yourself and your creations.  You will play and tweak "your" own adventures for hours!  There are so many cool things you can do and setup!  You really are creating your own adventures and feel very good about them!  It's an incredible feeling of great accomplishment!!!  I never really scripted before this game…  You are limited to flat level designs, but can link levels together with stairs, pits and teleports.I could go into greater detail, but just know, the level editor is awesome and will burn up your spare time fast!  You set the lighting by adding torches and/or more modern lights.  You can create some super creepy settings and add different monsters or monster spawn points to them!  If you want to just build a simple arena with endless spawning monsters that you control by the flip of a switch, you can do that too!  You can add different items to each monster so they drop different items, weapons and armor!  You have a lot of control and options and it is so simple to use!  Then, you can play them in the full game and even share them online in the Steam Workshop!  How freaking cool is that!!!  I will eventually be posting mine to try, and it is really good if I might say so myself! :-)Here are my system specifications: Apple iMac, i5 Quad-Core Intel processor 3.1GHZ, AMD Radeon HD 6970M with 1GB dedicated video RAM, 4GB system RAM, 1TB hard drive running OS X version 10.6.8, Journaled HFS+ Extended file system.
